421.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. (en)

421.21.Label: Flutes with external duct
421.21.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. (en)

421.211.Label: (Single) flutes with external duct
421.211.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. (en)

421.211.1.Label: Open flutes with external duct
421.211.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is open. (en)

421.211.11.Label: Open flutes with external duct without fingerholes
421.211.11.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has no fingerholes. China, Borneo. (en)

421.211.12.Label: Open flutes with external duct with fingerholes
421.211.12.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Indonesia. (en)

421.211.2.Label: Partly-stopped flutes with external duct
421.211.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole. Malacca. (en)

421.211.3.Label: Stopped flutes with external duct
421.211.3.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is closed. (en)

421.212.Label: Sets of flutes with external duct
421.212.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. In each flute, a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The flutes are joined to form a set. Tibet. (en)

421.22.Label: Flutes with internal duct
421.22.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. (en)

421.221.Label: (Single) flutes with internal duct
421.221.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the single tube. (en)

421.221.1.Label: Open flutes with internal duct
421.221.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is open. (en)

421.221.11.Label: Open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes
421.221.11.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is open. The instrument has no fingerholes. European signalling whistle. (en)

421.221.12.Label: Open flutes with internal duct with fingerholes
421.221.12.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Recorder. (en)

421.221.2.Label: Partly-stopped flutes with internal duct
421.221.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole. India and Indonesia. (en)

421.221.3.Label: Stopped flutes with internal duct
421.221.3.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is closed. (en)

421.221.31.Label: Stopped flutes with internal duct, without fingerholes
421.221.31.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is closed. The instrument has no fingerholes. (en)

421.221.311.Label: Stopped flutes with internal duct, without fingerholes with fixed stopped lower end
421.221.311.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is has a fixed stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. European signalling whistle. (en)

421.221.312.Label: Stopped flutes with internal duct, without fingerholes with adjustable stopped lower end
421.221.312.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube has an adjustable stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. Piston pipes [swannee whistle]. (en)

421.221.32.Label: Stopped flutes with internal duct, with fingerholes
421.221.32.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is closed. The instrument has fingerholes. Morocco. (en)

421.221.4.Label: Vessel flutes with duct
421.221.4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel. (en)

421.221.41.Label: Vessel flutes with duct, without fingerholes
421.221.41.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, without fingerholes. Zoomorphic pottery whistles (Europe, Asia). (en)

421.221.42.Label: Vessel flutes with duct, with fingerholes
421.221.42.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, with fingerholes. (en)

421.221.421.Label: Vessel flutes with duct, with single fingerhole
421.221.421.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, with a single fingerhole. Dog whistles etc. (en)

421.221.422.Label: Vessel flutes with duct, with two or more fingerholes
421.221.422.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, with two or more fingerholes. Ocarina. (en)

421.222.Label: Sets of flutes with internal duct
421.222.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. (en)

421.222.1.Label: Sets of open flutes with internal duct
421.222.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. (en)

421.222.11.Label: Sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes
421.222.11.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. The instrument has no fingerholes. Open flue stops of the organ. (en)

421.222.11+421.222.3.Label: Sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes combined with set of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct
421.222.11+421.222.3.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more pipes with open end are combined with two more more pipes with closed end. The instrument has no fingerholes. Organ with both open flue and Rohrflöte stops. (en)

421.222.11+421.222.3-8.Label: Sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes combined with set of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct with keyboard
421.222.11+421.222.3-8.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more pipes with open end are combined with two more more pipes with closed end. The instrument has no fingerholes. With keyboard. (en)

421.222.11-9.Label: Mechanically driven sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes
421.222.11-9.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. The instrument has no fingerholes.  With mechanical drive. (en)

421.222.12.Label: Sets of open flutes with internal duct with fingerholes
421.222.12.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Double flageolet. (en)

421.222.2.Label: Sets of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct
421.222.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is partly stopped. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. Rohrflöte stops of the organ. (en)

421.222.3.Label: Sets of stopped flutes with internal duct
421.222.3.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is closed. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. Stopped flue stops of the organ. (en)

421.222.4.Label: Sets of dissimilar flutes with internal duct
421.222.4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more flutes of more than one kind (open, partly-stopped or stopped) are combined to form a set. (en)

421.23.Label: Flutes with duct formed by an internal baffle with an external cover
421.23.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is formed by an internal baffle (natural node, block of resin) and an external tied-on cover (cane, wood, hide). American Plains, S. E. Asia, Indonesia. (en)

422.Label: Reedpipes
422.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a lamella. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. (en)

422.1.Label: Reedpipes with double (or quadruple) reeds
422.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem) which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. (en)

422.11.Label: Single reedpipes with double (or quadruple) reeds
422.11.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. (en)

422.111.Label: (Single) oboes with cylindrical bore
422.111.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore. (en)

422.111+422.211.Label: Single oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a single reedpipe with single reed
422.111+422.211.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In the single-reed reedpipe, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Cornemuse. (en)

422.111+422.22.Label: Single oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reed
422.111+422.22.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In each pipe of the set of single-reed reedpipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Northumbrian small-pipes, Scottish small-pipes. (en)

422.111.1.Label: (Single) oboes with cylindrical bore, without fingerholes
422.111.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore and is without fingerholes. British Columbia. (en)

422.111.2.Label: (Single) oboes with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes
422.111.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore. The instrument has fingerholes. It is tuned by altering the length of the air column. Aulos, crumhorn. (en)

422.111.2+422.211.1.Label: Cylindrical double-reed chanter with stopped end +  cylindrical single-reed drone

422.111.2+422.211.1-62.Label: Cylindrical double-reed chanter with stopped end + cylindrical single-reed drone; flexible air reservoir
422.111.2+422.211.1-62.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In the single-reed reedpipe, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir. (en)

422.111.2+422.22-62.Label: Single oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reed with flexible air reservoir
422.111.2+422.22-62.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In each pipe of the set of single-reed reedpipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. 422.111.2-5.Label: (Single) wind-cap oboes with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes

423.211.Label: Labrosones with fingerholes, with cylinder bore
423.211.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a tube with a predominantly cylindrical bore, and holes to modify the pitch. Key trumpet. (en)

423.211-71-4.Label: Labrosones with fingerholes and with keys, with cylinder bore and with crooks
423.211-71-4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a tube with a predominantly cylindrical bore, and holes to modify the pitch. With keys. With lengths of tube (crooks etc.) to set nominal pitches preparatory to playing. (en)

423.212.Label: Labrosones with fingerholes with (narrow) conical bore
423.212.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a tube with a narrow conical bore, and holes to modify the pitch. Cornetti. (en)

423.213.Label: Labrosones with fingerholes, with (wider) conical bore
423.213.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a tube with a wide conical bore, and holes to modify the pitch. Key bugles, serpents. (en)

423.213-71.Label: Labrosones with fingerholes and with keys, with (wider) conical bore
423.213-71.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a tube with a wide conical bore, and holes to modify the pitch. With keys. (en)

423.22.Label: Labrosones with slides
423.22.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a tube with a telescopic section that can be extended while it is played to modify the pitch. Europe slide trumpet, trombone (this category includes slide trombones with one or two thumb valves). (en)

423.23.Label: Labrosones with valves
423.23.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Europe. (en)

423.231.Label: Valve bugles
423.231.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a predominantly conical bore, and can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. (en)

423.231.1.Label: Valve bugles with narrow bore
423.231.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a predominantly conical, narrow bore, and can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. (en)

423.231.11.Label: Valve bugles with narrow bore, with short air column (less than 2 m)
423.231.11.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the short air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a predominantly conical, narrow bore, and can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Flugel horn. (en)

423.231.12.Label: Valve bugles with narrow bore, with long air column (more than 2 m)
423.231.12.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the long air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a predominantly conical, narrow bore, and can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Wagner tuba. (en)

423.231.2.Label: Valve bugles with wide bore
423.231.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a predominantly conical, wide bore, and can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Euphonium, tuba. (en)

423.231.2-4.Label: Valve bugles with wide bore and with crooks
423.231.2-4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a predominantly conical, wide bore, and can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. With lengths of tube (crooks etc.) to set nominal pitches preparatory to playing. (en)

423.232.Label: Valve horns
423.232.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. (en)

423.232.1.Label: Valve horns with narrow bore
423.232.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a narrow bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. (en)

423.232.11.Label: Valve horns with narrow bore, with short air column (less than 2 m)
423.232.11.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the short air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a narrow bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Cornet, F alto horn, B flat altissimo horn. (en)

423.232.11-4.Label: Valve horns with narrow bore, with short air column (less than 2 m) and with crooks
423.232.11-4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the short air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a narrow bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. With lengths of tube (crooks etc.) to set nominal pitches preparatory to playing. (en)

423.232.12.Label: Valve horns with narrow bore, with long air column (more than 2 m)
423.232.12.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the long air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a narrow bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Most french horns. (en)

423.232.12-4.Label: Valve horns with narrow bore, with long air column (more than 2 m) and with crooks
423.232.12-4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the long air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a narrow bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. With lengths of tube (crooks etc.) to set nominal pitches preparatory to playing. (en)

423.232.2.Label: Valve horns with wider bore
423.232.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a wider bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Althorn; tenor and baritone saxhorns. (en)

423.232.2-4.Label: Valve horns with wider bore and with crooks
423.232.2-4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a wider bore profile that is intermediate between conical and cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. With lengths of tube (crooks etc.) to set nominal pitches preparatory to playing. (en)

423.233.Label: Valve trumpets
423.233.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a bore profile that is predominantly cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. (en)

423.233.1.Label: Valve trumpets with short air column (less than 2 m)
423.233.1.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the short air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a bore profile that is predominantly cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Most valve trumpets. (en)

423.233.1-4.Label: Valve trumpets with short air column (less than 2 m) and with crooks
423.233.1-4.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the short air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a bore profile that is predominantly cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. With lengths of tube (crooks etc.) to set nominal pitches preparatory to playing. (en)

423.233.2.Label: Valve trumpets with long air column (more than 2 m)
423.233.2.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the long air column which is to be made to vibrate. The tubular body has a bore profile that is predominantly cylindrical. The body can be lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube. Most valve trombones. (en)

424.Label: Membranopipes
424.Description: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air column is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a membrane that periodically opens and closes an aperture. (en)

5.Label: Electrophones
5.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources, electronically stored data, electronic circuitry or materials that produce acoustic sound (unmodified acoustic instruments with attached microphones or pickups are classed within groups 1-4, according to the primary source of sound). (en)

51.Label: Electro-acoustic instruments and devices
51.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms (often resembling traditional acoustic instruments) and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. (en)

511.Label: Electro-acoustic idiophones
511.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. Material vibrates mechanically owing to its solidity and elasticity to provide input to a transducer (pick-up). (en)

512.Label: Electro-acoustic membranophones
512.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electric signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. A tightly stretched membrane vibrates to provide input to a transducer (pick-up). (en)

513.Label: Electro-acoustic chordophones
513.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. One or more strings stretched between fixed points vibrate to provide input to a transducer (pick-up). (en)

514.Label: Electro-acoustic aerophones
514.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. Vibrating bodies of air or vibrating reeds provide input to transducers (microphones or pick-ups). (en)

515.Label: Transducers
515.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound.   The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. (en)

52.Label: Electromechanical instruments and devices
52.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. (en)

521.Label: Tone wheel instruments
521.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The patterns are encoded on a wheel and read electromagnetically or electrostatically. (en)

522.Label: Photo-electric electromechanical instruments
522.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The encoded patterns are read photoelectrically. (en)

523.Label: Record/playback devices
523.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The encoded patterns are recorded, and read in playing back electromagnetically or electrostatically. (en)

524.Label: Electromechanical samplers
524.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The encoded patterns are samples. (en)

525.Label: Electromechanical sound processing devices
525.Description: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. Devices to modify signals electromechanically. (en)

53.Label: Analogue electronic instruments, modules and components
53.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. (en)

531.Label: Analogue synthesizers and other electronic instruments with thermionic valve (vacuum-tube) or solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals
531.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with thermionic valve (vacuum-tube) or solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. (en)

531.1.Label: Analogue synthesizers and other electronic instruments with thermionic valve (vacuum-tube) based devices generating and/or processing electric sound signals
531.1.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with thermionic valve (vacuum-tube) based devices generating and/or processing electric sound signals. (en)

531.2.Label: Analogue synthesizers and other electronic instruments with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals
531.2.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. (en)

531.21.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using additive synthesis
531.21.Description: Electric signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. The devices use additive synthesis. (en)

531.22.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using subtractive synthesis
531.22.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. The devices use subtractive synthesis. (en)

531.221.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using subtractive synthesis - modular synthesizers
531.221.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. These modular devices use subtractive synthesis. (en)

531.222.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using subtractive synthesis - pre-set synthesizers
531.222.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electricc sound signals. These pre-set devices use subtractive synthesis. (en)

531.222.1.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using subtractive synthesis - pre-set monophnic synthesizers
531.222.1.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. These pre-set devices use subtractive synthesis to play only one note at a time. (en)

531.222.2.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using subtractive synthesis - pre-set partially or fully polyphonic synthesizers
531.222.2.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. These pre-set devices use subtractive synthesis and can play more than one note at a time. (en)

531.23.Label: Analogue synthesizers with solid state circuitry based devices generating and processing electric sound signals using hybrid subtractive and additive synthesis
531.23.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals with solid state circuitry (transistor and/or analogue integrated circuitry) generating and/or processing electric sound signals. These devices use both subtractive and additive synthesis. (en)

532.Label: Voltage control sources
532.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. These devices use voltage control sources. (en)

532.1.Label: Voltage control sources - control voltage sequence generators
532.1.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. The devices use voltage control sources. Voltages are controlled by an envelope generator, a low-frequency oscillator, sequencer, slew generator, peak amplitude follower, envelope follower, or sample and hold. (en)

532.2.Label: Voltage control sources - controleers and interfaces
532.2.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. These devices use voltage control sources. Voltages are controlled by human interface devices, keyboards, foot switches, sensors, wheels or touchpads. (en)

533.Label: Other analogue modules or configurations
533.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. The modules contain analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. The devices use analogue modules or configurations other than voltage control sources and interfaces. (en)

533.1.Label: Analogue modules
533.1.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Modules containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. (en)

533.11.Label: Analogue modules: audio signal generators
533.11.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Modules containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. These analogue modules use audio signal generators: oscillators producing sine, square, and saw tooth waves, beat frequency oscillators or heterodyne systems. (en)

533.12.Label: Analogue modules: signal modifiers or processors
533.12.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Modules containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. These analogue modules use analogue signal combining, modifying, reproducing and processing devices. Mixers, sum/difference/multiple output generators etc., timbre modifiers, filter devices. (en)

533.2.Label: Analogue configurations
533.2.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Configurations containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. The devices use analogue configurations: mixer consoles (also containing filters, ring modulators etc), sequencer-based configurations, experimental configurations, or sound sculptures. (en)

533.3.Label: Modules communicating between devices/signal convertors other than transducers
533.3.Description: Continuously varying electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electrical signals are generated using electronic circuitry. Modules containing analogue fully electronic devices used to produce, process and communicate electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. The devices use modules communicating between devices/signal convertors other than transducers. (en)

54.Label: Digital instruments, modules and components
54.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Modules and configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. (en)

541.Label: Digital synthesizers with fixed keyboard controllers
541.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. (en)

541.1.Label: Digital synthesizers using frequency modulation
541.1.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using frequency modulation synthesis. (en)

541.11.Label: Digital synthesizers using frequency modulation synthesis, without fixed keyboard controllers
541.11.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using frequency modulation synthesis, without fixed keyboard controllers. (en)

541.12.Label: Digital synthesizers using frequency modulation synthesis, with fixed keyboard controllers
541.12.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using  electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using frequency modulation synthesis, with fixed keyboard controllers. (en)

541.2.Label: Digital synthesizers using additive synthesis
541.2.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using additive synthesis. (en)

541.21.Label: Digital synthesizers using additive synthesis, without fixed keyboard controllers
541.21.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using additive synthesis without fixed keyboard controllers. (en)

541.22.Label: Digital synthesizers using additive synthesis, with fixed keyboard controllers
541.22.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using additive synthesis with fixed keyboard controllers. (en)

541.3.Label: Digital synthesizers using phase distortion techniques
541.3.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using phase distortion techniques. (en)

541.31.Label: Digital synthesizers using phase distortion techniques, without fixed keyboard controllers
541.31.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker. The electrical signals are generated using electronically stored data and electronic circuitry. Configurations containing devices to digitally design and process electronic sound signals and/or sequences of signals. Digital synthesizers using phase distortion techniques, without fixed keyboard controllers. (en)

541.32.Label: Digital synthesizers using phase distortion techniques, with fixed keyboard controllers
541.32.Description: Electrical signals are generated in the form of quantized sequences of pulses. These are converted to continuous signals that activate a loudspeaker.
